name: Kato's conjecture
rephrased: Does the square root of a uniformly complex elliptic operator, defined via functional calculus, have an analytic domain?
implication_form: If an operator is uniformly complex elliptic, then its square root (defined via functional calculus) has an analytic domain.
explained: Kato's conjecture concerns the analyticity properties of the square root of certain types of elliptic operators. It posits that for a uniformly complex elliptic operator L (typically acting on vector-valued functions over a domain in R^n), defined on a bounded Lipschitz domain Ω, the square root √L (defined via functional calculus) is an analytic function on Ω. The precise statement often involves the boundedness and analyticity of the related Dirichlet-to-Neumann map or the Poisson operator associated with the operator L.
related_conjectures: Kato square root problem (for other operators/scales)
Douglas-Rachford conjecture (related to operator theory, sometimes cited in the context of related functional calculus)
Hodge conjecture (related via elliptic complexes like the Hodge Laplacian)
